awd_titl_txt: UTRGV-UMN PARTNERSHIP FOR FOSTERING INNOVATION by BRIDGING EXCELLENCE in RESEARCH and STUDENT SUCCESS
awd_abstract_narration:
****Non-Technical Abstract****
The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV) is a new institution resulting from the merger of the University of Texas Pan American (UTPA) and UT Brownsville (UTB). UTRGV will open its doors in September 2015 as an emerging research institution with a new medical school. UTRGV will open with over 30,000 students being 89% Hispanic. The proposed UTRGV-UMN PREM partnership will provide opportunities to develop research and education infrastructure. This PREM will directly impact over 140 students (20 M.S. and 120 B.S.) most of whom will be first generation college students from underrepresented groups. The state of the art proposed research, combined with the PIs experience in leading successful scholarly enterprises presents an opportunity to further develop basic knowledge and technology in materials science while strengthening the STEM workforce by equipping students with the necessary knowledge, skills and abilities to thrive. The PIs have a strong track record of working with UG students, and will mentor junior faculty to further improve student success through research projects. The PREM team will disseminate acquired knowledge in peer-reviewed journal articles, conference presentations, and multiple outreach activities to K-12 students and teachers.  

****Technical Summary****
The PREM team will combine efforts from seven different departments within UTRGV and three from UMN to promote fundamental understanding and development of technology. Specifically, the selected subprojects are: (1) Magnetoelectric Effects in Perovskite Complex Metal Oxides; (2) Nonflammable, Ionic Liquid-Based Electrolytes for Safer Lithium-ion Batteries; (3) Synthesis of Conjugated Polymers for Photovoltaics and Electrolyte Gated Transistors; (4) Homeostasis of Cultured Mammalian Cells in a Nanofiber Environment Development of NFs for bio-related applications; and (5) Cellular Imaging Using Persistent Luminescent Spinel Nanoparticles.  These projects will: (a) aim in the development of students with strong analytical skills, creativity/innovation, teamwork, leadership, and work ethics to become visionaries and entrepreneurs in the materials science workforce; (b) promote an exchange of faculty and students between UMN/UTRGV; (c)  raise STEM awareness in K-12 students while increasing awareness of innovation and creative thinking among K-12 teachers; and (d) improve UTRGV's research, academic, and community infrastructure, to promote long term growth and sustainability.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY

por.por_cntn:
Our PREM program focused on development of human capital and infrastructure by bridging fundamental and engineering research on nanomaterials with innovation in the development of devices and systems. Out goals were: 1.- To expand and consolidate a multidisciplinary team of researchers (seven departments are represented) into a sustainable Materials Science Research Center of Excellence. 2.- To enhance the technical partnership with UMN with continuing joint success in education and outreach. 3.- To provide junior faculty with a research platform to promote their Materials Science Research (MSR)/education careers. Faculty enrichment, in return, promotes student development and success. 4.- To continue to build the Tier I pipeline of minority students, to overcome the underrepresentation of scientists and engineers. 5.- To increase technological and scientific awareness in K-12 and the RGV community in general.

A.-Intellectual Merit

Our PREM project experienced COVID-19 lockdown and afterward effects, strategic plans were implemented to ensure continuation of the research projects and more importantly a safe space where our students ?could get away? from COVID. The lab stayed operational and accessible through strict logistics. PREM stayed active, opportunities for our students never stopped. The team published over 25 journal articles during COVID lockdown time. In total over the grant period, the team published 128 peer reviewed articles and gave 262 oral/poster presentations. Some of the contributions to the body of knowledge depicted in the above mentioned publications is mentioned below.

The team led by Dr. Alcoutlabi and Dr. Lodge successfully researched the effect of temperature and additives on the ionic conductivity of mixed organic/ionic liquid electrolytes by conducting galvanostatic cell charge/discharge and ionic conductivity experiments as well as the effect of electrolyte type on the electrochemical performance of novel battery arrangements. The team also synthesized flexible and binder-free ceramic/carbon composite-fiber anodes for lithium-ion and sodium-ion batteries. Dr. Gilkerson's team focused on developing methods to increase cell adhesion and viability on nanofiber membranes by including bioactive carbohydrate groups and extracellular matrix components, such as fibronectin and collagen. Antibacterial activity for wound dressing applications was also evaluated. The team led by Dr. Martirosyan was able to synthesize and characterize complex systems such as perovskite ferrites, bismuth ferrites, lithium niobate, cobaltites and manganites to develop magnetoelectric materials. The team led by Dr. Uddin worked on the development of novel film based triboelectric systems. 

B.- Broader Impacts

The developed projects showed strong promise towards solving existent challenges in broad areas. But more so, the team provided research opportunities to 203 students (136 UG, 62 MS and 5 H.S.), 87% of them were co-authors of the published peer reviewed journal articles. Over 90% of the students are Hispanics, and over 25% women, exciting statistics way above the national percentages reported by National Science Board Indicators 2020 (3% Engineering Hispanic female in 2018). One Hispanic female engineer who graduated from this PREM cycle (2016) have successfully defended his dissertation from Texas A&M in Materials Science. Nez Izquierdo also a former UTRGV UG student received his PhD from UMN MRSEC. 

Regarding Education and Outreach the activities were uniquely successful and strong despite the unforeseen lockdown. The team started to get involved in the organization of the Rio Grande Valley, Regional Science and Engineering Fair, we have organized all fairs starting from the 60th and then 61st which was virtual, finally we are back to face to face. The PREM team also participated in TAME, Gear-Up and several other STEM k-12 activities as well as numerous college and professional outreach activities such as SHPEtinas and WeSTEM virtual events. 34 UG students participated in the UMN Summer Research Experiences. 58% of the graduating UG students pursued graduate programs. The opportunity to participate in research projects has proven to be an excellent platform to promote strong mentoring, which has shown promising results to engage the students in their studies and eventually increase retention and graduation rates. During the lifetime of the grant, the PREM team had 100% retention and graduation. 

 


Last Modified: 09/13/2023
Modified by: Karen Lozano
